{{good article}} {{Infobox Hurricane | Name=Hurricane Hilda | Year=1955 | Basin=Atl | Type=hurricane | Formed=September 10, 1955 | Dissipated=September 20, 1955 | Image location=September 19, 1955 Hurricane Hilda map.jpg | Image name=Mid-level [[geopotential height]] map of Hilda making landfall | 1-min winds=110 | Pressure=952 | Damages=120 | Fatalities=304 direct | Areas=[[Hispaniola]], [[Cuba]], [[Cayman Islands]], [[Yucatán Peninsula]], Mainland [[Mexico]] | Hurricane season=[[1955 Atlantic hurricane season]] }} '''Hurricane Hilda''' was a strong [[Saffir–Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 3]] [[Atlantic hurricane|hurricane]] that was the second in a succession of three hurricanes to strike near [[Tampico]], [[Mexico]]. The eighth [[tropical cyclone naming|named storm]] of the [[1955 Atlantic hurricane season]], Hilda formed from a [[tropical wave]] on September 10 near the [[Lesser Antilles]]. It quickly intensified while moving westward into a small hurricane, and it crossed over southeastern [[Cuba]] on September 13. There, it dropped heavy rainfall and produced gusty winds that destroyed 80% of the coffee crop in [[Oriente Province]]. In the eastern Cuban city of [[Baracoa]], Hilda severely damaged the oldest church in the country. Damage totaled $2 million in Cuba, and there were four deaths. Later, the hurricane moved across the Caribbean Sea, causing light damage in the sparsely populated region of the eastern [[Yucatán Peninsula]].
After reaching the Gulf of Mexico, Hilda strengthened to reach peak winds of 125 mph (205 km/h) late on September 18. Before the hurricane moved ashore, there was residual flooding in Tampico from earlier [[1955 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Gladys|Hurricane Gladys]]. Hilda struck the city early on September 19, with gusts estimated at {{convert|150|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. It dropped heavy rainfall that flooded 90% of Tampico, while its strong winds damaged half of the homes, leaving 15,000 homeless. The storm killed 300 people and caused over $120 million (1955 [[United States dollar|USD]]) in Mexico. Ongoing flooding caused an outbreak of [[dysentery]], and about 10 days after Hilda struck, [[Hurricane Janet]] struck the same region and caused further flooding and damage. Collectively, the damage from the storms represented about half of Mexico's budget in 1955.
==Meteorological history== {{storm path|Hilda 1955 track.png}} The origins of Hurricane Hilda were from an [[tropical wave|easterly wave]],<ref name="mwr">{{cite report|author=Gordon E. Dunn|author2=Walter R. Davis|author3=Paul L. Moore|title=Hurricanes of 1955|publisher=United States Weather Bureau|page=320|accessdate=January 20, 2013|date=December 1955|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1955.pdf}}</ref> which spawned a tropical depression over the northern [[Lesser Antilles]] late on September 10.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} By the next day, the system was producing winds of {{convert|46|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in squalls.<ref name="clim"/> After moving to the northwest, it turned more to the west and quickly intensified.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} On September 12, Hilda attained hurricane status to the north of the [[Mona Passage]] between [[Puerto Rico]] and the [[Dominican Republic]]. It was a small cyclone, and the strongest winds were in a small region around the [[eye (cyclone)|eye]].<ref name="mwr"/> Hilda continued to the west about {{convert|30|mi|km|abbr=on}} offshore northern [[Hispaniola]].<ref name="clim"/> After reaching winds of 100 mph (160 km/h), the hurricane weakened slightly while off the north coast of [[Haiti]]. Turning to the west-southwest, Hilda made [[landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] near the southeastern tip of [[Cuba]] on September 13. While crossing the island into the [[Caribbean Sea]], it weakened from a hurricane into a tropical storm.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}}
On September 14, Hilda emerged into the Caribbean Sea. It quickly re-intensified, surpassing its previous strength to winds of {{convert|115|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} by September 15.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} The hurricane weakened slightly as it neared the [[Yucatán Peninsula]], and Hilda struck the sparsely populated area between [[Chetumal]] and [[Cozumel]] on September 16 with winds of about {{convert|110|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}}<ref name="mwr"/> It weakened slightly over the Yucatán Peninsula, emerging into the [[Gulf of Mexico]] on September 17 with winds of about 100 mph (160 km/h). Hilda again re-intensified, reaching its [[maximum sustained wind]]s of 125 mph (205 km/h) late on September 18.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} Early the next day, the hurricane made landfall near [[Tampico, Tamaulipas]] in northeastern Mexico. Winds in the city reached {{convert|105|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, and the eye was observed for 45 minutes. The lowest pressure in Tampico was {{convert|952|mbar|inHg|abbr=on}} on September 19.<ref name="mwr"/> Hilda rapidly weakened over land, turning to the west-southwest and dissipating on September 20.<ref name="mwr"/>
==Impact== Early in its duration, the storm produced winds of {{convert|55|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} on [[Grand Turk Island]]. Its threat prompted a [[small craft advisory]] for southern Florida,<ref>{{cite news|agency=United Press|title=Naval Base in Path of Hurricane|newspaper=The Times-News|date=September 13, 1955|accessdate=January 20, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BUIaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hyMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4098,4024197&dq=hurricane+cuba&hl=en}}</ref> the southern Bahamas, and Cuba.<ref name="day">{{cite news|newspaper=Daytona Beach Morning Journal|title=Hurricane Loses Its Punch|date=1955-09-14|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=January 20, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=C4oeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fcsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2365,1661728&dq=hurricane+cuba&hl=en}}</ref> When Hilda struck southeastern Cuba, it caused moderate damage and killed four people,<ref name="mwr"/> all of whom in [[Oriente Province]].<ref name="sara"/> Wind gusts reached {{convert|45|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[Guantanamo Bay Naval Base]],<ref name="day"/> which caused a brief power outage.<ref name="tol"/> High waves washed a freighter ashore along Cuba's north coast.<ref name="day"/> Strong winds severely damaged the church in [[Baracoa]], which was built in the 16th century and was the oldest in the country.<ref name="sara"/> In [[Santiago de Cuba]], Hilda produced heavy rains and gusty winds, which knocked down telephone lines and caused flooding.<ref name="tol">{{cite news|title=Hurricane Loses Force in Cuba|date=September 14, 1955|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=Toledo Blade|accessdate=January 20, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gZ5OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mgAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7314,4182212&dq=hurricane+cuba&hl=en}}</ref> Five people were injured after houses collapsed in the city. High rains and winds damaged the sugar cane and pineapple crop,<ref name="sara"/> and destroyed 80% of the coffee crop in Oriente Province.<ref name="lewis"/> Damage in the country was not severe,<ref name="sara">{{cite news|title=Cuba Damaged by Hilda; Ione Brews|newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|date=September 16, 1955|agency=United Press|accessdate=January 20, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5SEhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7GQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6315,2485405&dq=hurricane+cuba&hl=en}}</ref> estimated at $2 million.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Roger A. Pielke Jr.|author2=Jose Rubiera|author3= Christopher Landsea|author4=Mario L. Fernández|author5=Roberta Klein|title=Hurricane Vulnerability in Latin America and The Caribbean: Normalized Damage and Loss Potentials|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|journal=National Hazards Review|date=August 2003|page=108|accessdate=January 20, 2013|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/NHR-Cuba.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> Hundreds of people were injured or left homeless.<ref name="spt">{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|title=Sluggish Ione Slowing Down Over Atlantic|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=September 16, 1955|accessdate=January 20, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CfcNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=eHoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6526,6105&dq=hurricane+yucatan&hl=en}}</ref> After the hurricane isolated the town of [[Caimanera]], American workers sent a train there from Guantanamo Bay with a medical team and supplies.<ref name="sara"/>
While Hilda moved across the western Caribbean, it produced winds of {{convert|55|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} on [[Grand Cayman Island]].<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Reading Eagle|date=September 15, 1955|title=Ione Veers|accessdate=January 20, 2013|agency=Associated Press|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fA0rAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bpoFAAAAIBAJ&dq=hurricane%20yucatan&pg=4645%2C5626348}}</ref> Ahead of Hilda's landfall on the Yucatán peninsula, officials warned the residents to prepare for high winds and waves.<ref name="lewis">{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|title=Hurricane Hilda Due To Hit The Yucatan Peninsular Tonight|date=September 15, 1955|newspaper=Lewiston Evening Journal|accessdate=January 20, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PT1HAAAAIBAJ&sjid=y_MMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1726,1362713&dq=hurricane+yucatan&hl=en}}</ref> A [[tropical cyclone warnings and watches|storm warning]] was issued in [[Belize City]].<ref name="spt"/> When Hilda crossed the Yucatán peninsula, it caused about $100,000 in damage.<ref name="clim">{{cite book|page=326-328|title=Tropical Storms of the North Atlantic, September 1955|author=C.E. Rhodes|publisher=United States Weather Bureau|accessdate=January 20, 2013|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pRrOAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA326&dq=hurricane+hilda+1955&hl=en&sa=X&ei=I0r8UPvIA4nS9ASGsIAg&ved=0CC0Q6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=hurricane%20hilda%201955&f=false}}</ref> Ahead of the storm in South Texas, officials provided sandbags and advised businesses to move merchandise within {{convert|2|ft|m|abbr=on}} of the floor, both an effort to mitigate potential flooding.<ref>{{cite news|date=September 18, 1955|title=Hilda Strikes Mexican Island|newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=January 21, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6CEhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7GQEAAAAIBAJ&dq=hurricane%20hilda&pg=2288%2C3410409}}</ref> The large circulation produced winds of {{convert|22|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and flooded coastal roads in southern Texas.<ref name="clim"/> Outer rainbands flooded [[Raymondville, Texas|Raymondville]] and other towns in the region.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brazos River Settling Down Following Crest at Seymour|agency=Associated Press|date=September 29, 1955|newspaper=The Victoria Advocate|accessdate=January 21, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cGNTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dYUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5334,2998778&dq=hurricane+hilda&hl=en}}</ref>
Before the hurricane struck, residents in Mexico expected that Hurricane Hilda would be weaker and strike near Tampico. When the storm was announced via radio about three hours before landfall, most people were already asleep and unable to prepare.<ref name="asa">{{cite web|publisher=Así es Tampico|title=1955, the year that marked Tampico's History|accessdate=January 20, 2013|url=http://www.asiestampico.com.mx/ap_552.htm}}</ref> Tides rose in advance of the storm, and before it made landfall, 10% of Tampico was still flooded from previous [[1955 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Gladys|Hurricane Gladys]].<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Daytona Beach Morning Journal|title=Ione is Bypassing Florida|agency=Associated Press|date=September 18, 1955|accessdate=January 20, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DooeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fcsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=683,2178066&dq=hurricane+yucatan&hl=en}}</ref> In Tampico, Hilda's strong winds blew away an anemometer after the instrument recorded winds of {{convert|105|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}; peak winds were later estimated at around {{convert|150|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="mwr"/> At the city's port, Hilda damaged boats and ferries, some of which washed out to sea.<ref name="asa"/> The hurricane destroyed the roofs of about half of the city's houses, as well as several schools and large buildings. Hilda produced severe flooding in Tampico that was reported to have covered 90% of the city's streets.<ref name="clim"/> Although smaller than the previous Hurricane Gladys, Hilda dropped heavy rainfall that flooded local rivers. Overall, 11,432 people were directly affected by Hilda.<ref name="asa"/> The hurricane caused 300 deaths and $120 million in damage, mostly due to the flooding.<ref name="mwr"/>
After the storm, Tampico was left without power or communications.<ref name="asa"/> About 15,000 people became homeless due to the storm, or previously from Hurricane Gladys. The governor of Tamaulipas declared a state of emergency and requested assistance from the military to provide food and shelter. Within a day after the storm, water access was restored, although the city initially remained without power or telephone. Communications were cut to Tampico, except for the airport at the radio.<ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|date=September 20, 1955|title=Hilda Leaves 15,000 Homeless, 12 Dead, 350 Hurt in Tampico|newspaper=The Free Lance-Star|accessdate=January 20, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=M95LAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3ooDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4489,1088530&dq=hurricane+hilda&hl=en}}</ref> The rail line from [[Laredo, Texas]] to Mexico City was cut during the storm, but was restored ten days later.<ref>{{cite news|title=Floods Delay Reports of Janet's Mexico Toll|agency=Associated Press|date=September 30, 1955|newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|accessdate=January 21, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=hngcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5GQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4051,70280&dq=hurricane+hilda&hl=en}}</ref> Due to ongoing flood conditions, there was an outbreak of [[dysentery]] that killed two children. The Mexican government flew medical supplies, food, and clothing from Mexico City to Tampico, while four United States helicopters assisted in rescue missions along the Pánuco River.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Age|agency=Australian Associated Press|date=September 23, 1955|title=Disease Menaces Flooded City|accessdate=January 21, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7gAzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6JQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3588,3442039&dq=hurricane+hilda&hl=en}}</ref> About 10 days after Hilda struck Tampico, [[Hurricane Janet]] affected the same area, causing further damage and deaths. Collectively, the two hurricanes caused 1,240 deaths along their paths,<ref name="clim"/> and damage from the consecutive storms totaled about half of Mexico's 1955 national budget.<ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|date=September 30, 1955|title=Hurricane-Borne Deluge Floods Parts of Mexico|newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle|accessdate=January 21, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FOZXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sfYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3519,2531375&dq=hurricane+hilda&hl=en}}</ref> After the two hurricanes, the Mexican government and military worked to assist the affected residents, and the Mexican [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]] provided vaccinations and medical assistance to prevent the spread of disease.<ref name="asa"/>
